entries.title: We're Hiring Telecommuters - Grant Street Group
entries.text:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com

entries.title: A call to action for CPAN authors
entries.text: As with every upgrade we can expect that upgrading to perl 5.18 will break some code. Luckily the CPAN Testers provide a very good overview of which modules work and which stopped working due to changes in perl. David Oswald calls on all CPAN authors to make sure theyr module works on perl 5.18 as well. If you work in a corporate environment, it might be a good idea to check if all your dependencies and also your code works on 5.18. (See the other entry in Which David Golden explains how to set up multiple versions of perl on the same machine.)

entries.title: Compiler::Lexer is awesome / Shipped Perl::MinimumVersion::Fast
entries.text: Perl::MinimumVersion::Fast created by Tokuhiro Matsuno is 'just' 33 times faster than Perl::MinimumVersion. Oh. Oh!

entries.title: 5.18 Hash Key Ordering Changes In A Nutshell
entries.text: Mark Fowler shows the difference between perl 5.16.3 and the recently released perl 5.18.0 regarding hash keys.

entries.title: How I manage new perls with perlbrew
entries.text: There are cases whe you would like to make sure your code runs on more than one version of Perl. Either because you don't have control over which version of perl will be used, or because your company wants to make sure when upgrade comes, it will be smooth. David Golden explains how he uses perlbrew to have several versions of perl on his system.

entries.title: We want Perl on GAE!
entries.text: PHP was recently added to the Googl App Engine as one of the supported languages. Gianluca Casati things that it would be important to have Perl there, and that you can increase  the chances by star-in the request on the issue list of GAE.

entries.title: Last in the 5 Part Series...
entries.text: Rob Lauer started to build a cloud-based business using Perl. This is the last entry in his series about building the business.

entries.title: Perl, Python, Ruby, PHP and HTML5 on Google trends
entries.text: There are many ways to measure the 'market share' or 'mind share' of a programming language and the dynamics between languages. I tried to see how many people search for the respective terms and what are the trends in relative volume of searches.

entries.title: Simple Database access using Perl DBI and SQL
entries.text: If you don't know how to use databases with Perl, this is a simple introduction for you, already translated to several languages. If you do know how to use databases but don't know who is Little Bobby Tables, then you definietly need to take a look.

chapters.title: Events
chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
